quickFacts.name: Significance

title: Keweenaw NHP Park Store

images.altText: soon
images.title: KEWE Park Store
images.caption: The park store in the Calumet Visitor Center.

bodyText: The park store is operated by Isle Royale and Keweenaw Parks Association, an official non-profit partner of the National Park Service dedicated to supporting the educational mission of Keweenaw National Historical Park. The park store has a wide range of educational products and services available for retail sale. These products complement the interpretive themes you experience when visiting the park. The park store is located at the Calumet Visitor Center in downtown Calumet, or you can visit the online park store.
audioDescription: soon
managedByOrg: Isle Royale and Keweenaw Parks Association

title: Laurium Manor Mansion

images.altText: Fall scene of large three-story white house with grand entrance, wrapping porch, and brick chimney.
images.title: Laurium Manor Mansion
images.caption: Laurium Manor Mansion in Laurium, MI.

bodyText:
Thomas Hoatson Jr., owner of the Calumet & Arizona Mining Company, built this 45-room, 13,000 square foot home in 1908 using the finest and rarest building materials available. Mansion tours are self-guided and takes 30-60 minutes. Printed guide and smartphone audio tours are included. Lodging at the mansion is available year-round.

The Keweenaw Heritage Sites are official partners of Keweenaw National Historical Park, but are privately owned. Each site interprets and preserves an important aspect of the area's copper mining history and provides a unique visitor experience. Please contact individual sites for more information.
audioDescription: The Laurium Manor is located on Tamarack street between 3rd and 4th streets. This three-story mansion has white painted wooden siding. The front entrance has prominent red sandstone steps leading up from the sidewalk. Red sandstone blocks are also used as retaining walls in the yard and garden around the building. The front entrance is covered by a two-story gable roof with four ornate Romanesque pillars supporting it as it extends from the house. A porch sits on the second story of this entrance extension. Porches also wrap around the ground floor of the house and have covered roofs supported by smaller Romanesque columns like those in the front. A round set of windows on the front corner of the right side of the building harkens to Queen Anne style construction. The third floor has two dormer windows facing the road and a brick chimney rising from the back of the building. The manor was built by Thomas H and Cornelia Hoatson in 1908. Now the 13,000 square foot house serves as a bed and breakfast and also hosts tours so visitors can see the grand style some of Calumet’s residents used to live in.

title: Locomotive Shop
listingDescription: Railroad maintenance was essential to keeping C&H running smoothly.

images.altText: Winter scene of wood and poor-rock building with a large entrance, now boarded and sealed.
images.title: C&H Locomotive Shop
images.caption: The Calumet & Hecla Locomotive Shop.

bodyText: The locomotive shop was built in 1883 out of poor-rock with brick accents around some of the windows and doors. Here workers repaired company locomotives and rail stock here prior to the construction of the round house in 1888. It then served as a blacksmith and general repair shop for the Hecla & Torch Lake Railroad. Later it also served as a pipe and pole shop, and a machine shop.
audioDescription: The Locomotive shop is located just behind, northwest, of the Machine Shop. This single-story building has tall walls made of poor-rock and wood. From this perspective two gabled entrances for trains can be seen on the right and left of the building. Four smaller doors are between the two train entrances. On the left-hand face of the building three windows are visible with arched brick trim on top. In the center of the roof is a large ventilation stack. The Locomotive Shop is now surrounded by young birch trees, and most of the rail tracks surrounding it have been removed.

quickFacts.value: Contributing Structure to the Calumet National Historic Landmark District
quickFacts.name: Significance

title: Man Engine House
listingDescription: An early innovation in getting employees in and out of the mine.

images.altText: Winter scene of brick building with a ramp leading to its front door.
images.title: C&H Man engine House
images.caption: The Calumet & Hecla Man Engine House

bodyText: Originally this building housed a steam powered man engine. The building is a single-story brick structure with poor-rock foundation and hipped roof. This machine used a series of platforms that raised and lowered workers in and out of the mine, making for safer and faster entry than long ladders. Workers would step from one side of the moving platform to another as they paused. The building was later converted into a small warehouse and is now privately owned.
audioDescription: The Man Engine House is located northwest of Mine Street between the intersections of Depot St and Red Jacket Rd. This building has a mortared poor-rock foundation with the rest being constructed of red brick. The center of the building has a large set of two doors with an arched paneled window above. The doors and trim of the window are painted in a grey/brown color. On either side of the door are a paneled window set with an arched top. Either side of the building has three equally spaced paneled windows with an arched top. The roofline runs from each corner of the building to a single point at the top.

quickFacts.value: Contributing Structure to the Calumet National Historic Landmark District
quickFacts.name: Significance

title: Michigan Tech Archives

images.title: Michigan Tech Archives
images.caption: Michigan Tech Archives in Houghton, MI.

bodyText:
The Michigan Technological University Archives and Copper Country Historical Collections houses a wide variety of print, graphic and manuscript resources related to the history and culture the Copper Country and Michigan Technological University.

The Keweenaw Heritage Sites are official partners of Keweenaw National Historical Park, but are privately owned. Each site interprets and preserves an important aspect of the area's copper mining history and provides a unique visitor experience. Please contact individual sites for more information.
audioDescription: The Michigan Tech Archives are located on the campus of Michigan Technological University in the basement of the Van Pelt and Opie Library. The building has three stories and is built in a modern institutional style. It is made from concrete and has rectangular windows on the second and third stories. The ground floor has many open windows allowing patrons to see out and let natural light in. The archives host a wide collection of sources related to local history in formats like books, newspapers, photographs, and microfilm. The archives also have a wide range of its material available online.

title: Mine Captain's Office
listingDescription: Only the most experienced would ever be mine captains.

images.altText: Winter scene of a dark brown poor-rock building with wide light grey mortar lines.
images.title: C&H Mine Captain's Office
images.caption: The Calumet & Hecla Mine Captains Office.

bodyText: The mine captain’s office is located on the western end of Calumet’s industrial core. It is a single-story structure made from poor-rock with brick accents above the windows and doors. The first floor is raised above a partially submerged basement and the attic space has been finished. Mine captains, often skilled immigrants from distant mining regions, oversaw the daily mining operations underground. They frequently wore white for identification, marking their status compared to the dirty work of mining.
audioDescription: The Captain’s Office is in the V between Mine Street and the 6th Street Extension. This building is made from poor-rock. Large rocks have been cut for the corners of the building with smaller rocks used in the rest of the walls. Large light grey mortar lines can be seen between the rocks. The main entrance is in center of the front face of the building, raised off the ground and accessed by a set of metal stairs. A brick arch is located above the door and the line of a roof that once sat above the entrance can be seen in the wall. Two windows flank the entrance with brick arches above them. Two pane storm windows sit on the outside while the inside window is made of smaller panes. There is also a smaller window constructed in the same way above the door. Smaller windows are also located below the windows flanking the door at ground level. The sides of the buildings have two windows with brick arches and smaller ground-level windows as well. A square brick chimney can be seen coming out of the center of the roof.

quickFacts.value: Contributing Structure to the Calumet National Historic Landmark District
quickFacts.name: Significance

title: Miner's Memorial House
listingDescription: Many Quincy employees called this place home through the years.

images.altText: A park ranger speaks to a group of kids in front of a company house.
images.title: Miner's Memorial Company House
images.caption: A park ranger talks about company housing.

bodyText: The Copper Country has always been a remote location. To attract workers companies routinely built houses for their workers. This saltbox style home, built by the neighboring Pewabic Mining Company around 1870, had many occupants over the years. One was the family of Joseph Martin, who lived here with his wife and nine children. They left soon after Joseph lost his life in a mining accident in 1921. The house has undergone extensive stabilization and preservation in recent years.
audioDescription: Brown, two-story wooden house sits in an open grassy area approximately 200 feet to the north of the Hoist House. Behind the house is a former cooling pond in the shape of a narrow rectangle. To the north is a cluster of trees but in all other directions, the house has views of the former Quincy Mining surface ruins and operations: hoist house, #2 shaft-rockhouse, and rail stock parked along a grassy field in front of the house.

quickFacts.value: Contributing Structure to the Quincy Mining Company National Historic Landmark District
quickFacts.name: Significance

title: Mineral Range Railroad Depot

images.altText: Two story brick building with hipped metal roof.
images.title: Mineral Range Railroad Depot
images.caption: The Mineral Range railroad depot in Calumet, MI.

bodyText: Though vacant and quiet now, this railroad station once connected Red Jacket to faraway cities like Chicago and Milwaukee. Tears of joy and the chatter of various languages filled the air at this bustling entry point for the thousands of immigrants to the Copper Country. When the trains unloaded, family members might be reunited after months or sometimes years of separation. The original building, built in 1897, was made of wood. A new building was commissioned in 1908 to replace the wooden structure with the current brick building.
audioDescription: The Mineral Range Depot is located at the intersection of Ninth and Oak streets in downtown Calumet. The original depot was a single-story wooden structure with a hipped roof. A one-and-one-half story entrance was built on the south side of the depot. Between 1908 and 1917 the depot was re-built to a three-section brick building with a hipped roof and a wooden awning running around its entire perimeter. The central section is two stories tall with an office located on the western side. Two sets of double doors are located on the eastern face of this section with two rectangular windows between them. Rectangular double-pane windows are on the eastern and western faces of the second story. The southern section is a single-story with rectangular windows ringing it and a door located on this section’s southern face. The northern section was used as a baggage room and had rectangular double-pane windows ringing it. A brick chimney can be found in the center of the roof located between the central and northern building sections.

quickFacts.value: Contributing Structure to the Calumet National Historic Landmark District
quickFacts.name: Significance

title: Miscowaubik Club
listingDescription: This private club hosted many of the community elite.

images.altText: Winter scene of two-story house building with yellow wooden siding and a brick-based sign out front.
images.title: Miscowaubic Club
images.caption: The Miscowaubic Club.

bodyText: The Miscowaubik club was founded in 1903 and is named after a local Native American term for “Red Metal.” A former mine captain's house was turned into an exclusive social club frequented by the elite of the community and nation. Bowling, billiards, squash, and fine dining have been among the networking benefits available to members. The club has been active since 1903, hosting members of the Boston Brahmin and major industrialists.
audioDescription: The Miscowaubik Club is located on the northwest side of Calumet Ave between the intersections of Red Jacket Road and School Street. The front of the building that faces the road has a new main entrance that extends to the road from the main structure. A brick path leads from the sidewalk running along the road to the entrance. The portion of the main building closest to Calumet Ave is a single story with yellow wooden siding and seven two-panel windows. The main building sits in an L shape with the longer end running perpendicular to Calumet Ave. A detailed three-part window can be seen above the main entrance on the second story with an arch in the center of the three-paneled window. Brick chimneys can be seen on the northeast and northwest ends. The roof is covered in dark-grey asphalt shingles. The buildings foundation is a mix of blue-painted concrete and dark-grey poor rock with wide grout lines.

quickFacts.value: Contributing Structure to the Calumet National Historic Landmark District
quickFacts.name: Significance

title: Old Victoria

images.altText: Summer scene of log cabins with a wooden fence in the foreground and trees in the background.
images.title: Old Victoria
images.caption: Old Victoria in Rockland, MI.

bodyText:
Log cabins built at the Victoria Mine in 1899 served as homes to waves of copper miners and their families. Today visitors to Old Victoria can explore four historically furnished homes and hear stories about the men, women and children who once lived there.

The Keweenaw Heritage Sites are official partners of Keweenaw National Historical Park, but are privately owned. Each site interprets and preserves an important aspect of the area's copper mining history and provides a unique visitor experience. Please contact individual sites for more information.
audioDescription: The Old Victoria is located on Victoria Dam Road southwest of Rockland. This site has four historic cabins built by the Victoria Copper Mining Company in 1899. The cabins on the site are one to one-and-a-half story structures made from squared timbers. Windows are mostly rectangular and have two sets of six panes. The roofs are all covered in asphalt shingles. The cabins are not painted, and the logs are weathered to a medium-dark grey. Access to the site is through a gate in an historic wooden fence adjacent to the parking lot just of the road. Visitors to the site can experience guided tours which explain the history and daily lives of the miners who lived in these houses.

title: Ontonagon County Historical Museum

images.altText: Summer scene of periwinkle single-story modern building with flat roof.
images.title: Ontonagon County Historical Museum
images.caption: Ontonagon County Historical Historical Museum in Ontonagon, MI

bodyText:
The Ontonagon Historical Society was founded by local residents in 1957. The museum features exhibits on area mining, logging, farming, marine, and social memorabilia. Tours are provided of the nearby lighthouse which is the westernmost of Michigan’s lighthouses.

The Keweenaw Heritage Sites are official partners of Keweenaw National Historical Park, but are privately owned. Each site interprets and preserves an important aspect of the area's copper mining history and provides a unique visitor experience. Please contact individual sites for more information.
audioDescription: The Ontonagon Country Historical Society is located on River street between spar and Quartz streets in Ontonagon. The building is a single-story modern style painted periwinkle. It is built from concrete block and has wooden siding on the street side. The main entrance is located near the street and is a single pink door. Parking for the historical society is located directly next to the building. The museum hosts exhibits on maritime, copper mining, logging, and agriculture in the area. Visitors can also go on tours of the Ontonagon Harbor Lighthouse which is the westernmost lighthouse in Michigan and the oldest in the copper district.

title: Painesdale Mine and Shaft
listingDescription: Visit Painesdale Mine and Shaft.

images.altText: A tall rusty metal industrial building stands before blue skies.
images.title: Painesdale Mine Shaft
images.caption: Painesdale Mine & Shaft

bodyText:
By preserving and restoring the Champion #4 Shaft-Rockhouse, Painesdale Mine & Shaft, Inc. hopes to continue using it as a museum so that future generations can experience the sights, sounds, smells, and the feel of mining as it once was. Along with the #4 Shaft House, there remains numerous industrial buildings, railway equipment, and private homes related to the mining area. PM&S Inc. hopes to someday identify these structures so that the full story of what life was like in Painesdale can be told.

The Keweenaw Heritage Sites are official partners of Keweenaw National Historical Park, but are privately owned. Each site interprets and preserves an important aspect of the area's copper mining history and provides a unique visitor experience. Please contact individual sites for more information.
audioDescription: Within this former industrial landscape, stands a tall (100 foot) rusty, corrugated metal building. Other former industrial buildings are nearby. Interpretive panels explain the site. Private, once company-owned homes, are in the vicinity.

title: Parade Grounds

images.altText: Black and white historic image of men with rifles walking on a grassy field with a church behind.
images.title: Calumet Parade Grounds
images.caption: The former Calumet parade grounds.

bodyText: For many years, a grassy area along Calumet Ave between Depot Street and Red Jacket Road served as a parade ground. For generations, soldiers of the Calumet Light Guard, National Guard, and ROTC drilled here. Festivals were held on the grounds, and troops camped here during a major labor strike in 1913-14. Three of the buildings that stood on the edge of the parade ground (an armory, a church, and painting shop) are gone. Part of the parade ground is now occupied by new construction.
audioDescription: Once an open grassy field, it now houses a two story addition to Calumet Electronics. The building is a concrete structure with minimal windows and sits about 25 feet from highway US41, with a parking lot just to the north.

quickFacts.value: Contributing Structure to the Calumet National Historic Landmark District
quickFacts.name: Significance

title: Pattern Shop
listingDescription: Custom made wood patterns were fashioned by skilled woodworkers.

images.altText: Winter scene of yellow brick building with poor-rock foundation and red doors and windows.
images.title: C&H Pattern Shop
images.caption: The Calumet & Hecla Pattern Shop.

bodyText: Calumet & Hecla's location away from distant manufacturing centers required the company to be self-reliant. The pattern shop is located in the center of Calumet’s industrial core. The building is a large single-story structure made from yellow brick with a shallow-pitched gabled roof. Originally the building was divided in the center to house both a pattern workshop and warehouse. Here, skilled workers crafted patterns used in the foundry to cast needed parts or tools. The pattern shop is now home to Coppertown USA Mining Museum.
audioDescription: The Pattern Shop, which has been repurposed as the Coppertown USA Mining Museum, is located at the intersection of Red Jacket Road and Armory Drive. This large single-story building is constructed of yellow brick with a poor-rock foundation. There is a two-door entrance on the rear face of the building. To its left is a four-panel window comprised of six panes to each panel; the window framing is red. To the right of the entrance are four more windows of the same design. A large section of brick has been updated on the southwest side of the building and has a slightly redder color than the original brick. There is also a red double door entrance above the ground on this side which is accessed by metal stairs.

quickFacts.value: Contributing Structure to the Calumet National Historic Landmark District
quickFacts.name: Significance

title: Pattern Storage Warehouse
listingDescription: Thousands of patterns were made over C&H's lifetime.

images.altText: Winter scene of poor-rock two story building with red sandstone blocks on the building’s corners.
images.title: C&H Pattern Storage Warehouse
images.caption: The Calumet & Hecla Pattern Storage Warehouse.

bodyText: The pattern storage warehouse served as a giant repository for the over 30,000 patterns that Calumet & Hecla used with “green” sand to cast machine parts and tools. The building is a two-story structure made of poor-rock, red and white Jacobsville sandstone blocks on the corners, and brick trim above the windows and doors. A single-story dry house, a location for miners to hang their wet and dirty clothes after the shift, was attached to this building. You can compare a pattern warehouse to a 3D printer’s library of files.
audioDescription: The Pattern Storage Warehouse is located east of 6th Street and south of Armory Drive. The building is constructed from poor rock with clear light grey mortar lines. The corners of the buildings are made of large red and white striped sandstone blocks. The front of the building has a large two-door entrance with a brick arch above it. The wood of the doors has been weathered to a dark grey color. There are two sets of windows on either side of the entrance and are located above the door. Another window is located directly above the entrance door. Each window has a brick arch above it. To the left of the main entrance is a small single red door with a brick arch above it. The main portion of the building has a single pitch roof sloping from right to left. The other portion of the building is a single story, with its roof sloping from left to right, its left edge on the far-right wall of the main building. There is a single person entrance door painted in red in the center of the smaller section with a brick arch above it. Two windows flank this door with brick arches above them as well.

quickFacts.value: Contributing Structure to the Calumet National Historic Landmark District
quickFacts.name: Significance

title: Porcupine Mountains Wilderness State Park

images.altText: brick and wood building with steep asphalt shingled roof. A sign reads Wilderness Visitor Center
images.title: Porcupine Mountains State Park
images.caption: Porcupine Mountains Wilderness State Park in Ontonagon, MI.

bodyText:
In addition to wild forests and lakeshores, Michigan’s largest state park has numerous historic copper mining sites. The 59,020-acre park offers summer and winter recreational pursuits and interpretive programs. The park hosts a 35,000-acre old-growth forest amounts its waterfalls, rivers, trails, campgrounds, and Lake Superior shoreline.

The Keweenaw Heritage Sites are official partners of Keweenaw National Historical Park, but are privately owned. Each site interprets and preserves an important aspect of the area's copper mining history and provides a unique visitor experience. Please contact individual sites for more information.
audioDescription: The Porcupine Mountains Wilderness State Park is located southwest of Ontonagon and the visitor center is located on Headquarters Road. The visitor center is a tall single-story building which has a triangular shape. It is made from wood with a brick facade on the lower half of the walls. The steeply pitched roof has grey/brown asphalt shingles. The park was established in 1945 and includes nearly 60,000 acres. Visitors can experience over 90 miles of hiking trails, camping and lodging sites, old growth forest, and historic sites including a few marked copper mines.

title: Quincy #2 Shaft Rockhouse
listingDescription: Built by the American Bridge Company in 1908, the Quincy #2 Shaft rockhouse serves as a reminder of the Quincy legacy.

images.altText: A 140 foot industrial building (shafthouse) lit by the setting sun with dark cloudy skies behind.
images.title: Quincy #2 Shaft Rockhouse
images.caption: The Quincy #2 Shaft Rockhouse.

bodyText: A part of one of the Keweenaw’s most profitable and long-lasting copper mines, the No. 2 Shafthouse stands over the shaft where men would go underground to work and where copper-bearing rock was brought up from below. One of several mine shafts at the Quincy location, the #2 was the longest, extending over 9,000 feet along the angle and reaching an overall depth of 6,225 feet below the surface. Men mining on the 92nd level would have spent their entire 8-hour shift working more than a mile underground in 90-degree heat. Over time without use the shafthouse severely rusted, leading it to be resided in the mid-1980s - an early preservation effort by the Quincy Mine Hoist Association.
audioDescription: The prominent #2 shaft-rockhouse building is over 140 feet tall and can be seen for miles on top of Quincy Hill. The building is approximately 30 feet east of U.S. Highway 41 and has a large gravel parking lot to the north of the building. Visitors to the site park in this lot and can walk into the building's interior with the entrance located on the north side of the building. To the east, a tall metal pulley stand remains and was used to support the large cables that traveled from the hoist house into the shaft-rockhouse near the top of the building. At the base of this pulley stand, is a small rock masonry building. To the south of the shaft-rockhouse, are some abandoned wooden rail cars and beyond, an open landscape with stone foundations of former buildings. The building's height and unique shape are directly linked to the underground below. When positioned in the parking to the north and looking at the building, the roof angles down to the ground at a 50 degree angle. This same angle extends underground and is the angle by which skip cars and man engine cars traveled into the ground

quickFacts.value: Contributing Structure to the Quincy Mining Company National Historic Landmark District
quickFacts.name: Significance

title: Quincy #4 Boiler House

images.altText: Winter scene of collapsed poor-rock building with brick arch-topped windows.
images.title: Quincy #4 Boiler House
images.caption: The Quincy #4 Boiler House.

bodyText: The #4 Boiler House used its coal fired boilers to produce steam to power equipment such as hoisting engines. The boiler house was originally a two-story structure made from poor-rock with arched brick detailing above the windows and doors. Four boiler sets sat in brick surrounds inside the building. Two 18-foot tall stone chimneys sat next to the building, one on each of the northern and southern faces. Between 1888 and 1908 a single-story wooden addition was added onto the west corner of the building’s southern face. By 1942 the boiler house sat vacant and the boilers had been removed.
audioDescription: The #4 Boiler House is located southwest of the #2 Shaft House. The building still has its sloped north and south faces still standing along with most of the western wall. Bases of two chimneys on the north and the south of the building are also standing. The building is made from black poor-rock with evident grey mortar lines. Window frames on the north face of the building can be seen to have brick arches above them and some of the wooden sills remain. An arched doorway with brick top can also be seen on the north face. Holes where four windows would have set can be seen on the western face of the building.

quickFacts.value: Contributing Structure to the Quincy Mining Company National Historic Landmark District
quickFacts.name: Significance

title: Quincy #4 Hoist House

images.altText: Winter scene of poor-rock building ruin with brick-arch-topped windows and rough arched entrance.
images.title: Quincy #4 Hoist House
images.caption: The Quincy Mine #4 Hoist House.

bodyText: The #4 Boiler House provided power for lifting rock and moving workers at the #4 shaft.
audioDescription: The Number Four Hoist (Engine) House is located between the Number Four Boiler House and Number Seven Boiler House. The building is constructed from dark-grey poor rock with squared corners and prominent mortar lines. While the roof is no longer present, the engine house was originally two stories. The bottom story had two arched entrances on the south side. The second floor has numerous windows with brick arch tops.

quickFacts.value: Contributing Structure to the Quincy Mining Company National Historic Landmark District
quickFacts.name: Significance

title: Quincy #4 Shafthouse Ruins

images.altText: Spring scene of poor-rock building foundation.
images.title: Quincy #4 Shafthouse Ruins
images.caption: The Quincy Mine #4 Shafthouse ruins.

bodyText: Once a productive shaft for Quincy, the #4 plunged thousands of feet into the ground. The house itself was a 50-foot tall wooden building with a wire running southeast to the engine house. Today all that remains is the poor-rock foundation of the shafthouse. The building that used to cover the shaft allowed for some initial sorting of the ore coming from underground.
audioDescription: The Number Four Shaft Rock House is located west of the Number Four Engine House. Almost all the original structure is gone. What remains is a square poor-rock foundation with clear grey grout lines. The center of the structure has filled with dirt and now grows small shrubs and grass.

quickFacts.value: Contributing Structure to the Quincy Mining Company National Historic Landmark District
quickFacts.name: Significance

title: Quincy #5 Boiler House

images.altText: Winter scene of yellow brick building with roof partially removed.
images.title: Quincy #5 Boiler House
images.caption: The Quincy Mine #5 Boiler House

bodyText: The neighboring "world's largest steam hoist" required a massive amount of steam to operate. In the #5 Boiler House, eight coal-fired boilers boiled water, producing this steam. The building is a tall single-story structure made from yellow brick. A shorter single-story addition with gable roof can be seen on the southwestern face of the boiler house. Steel trusses supported the roof and the walls were covered in plaster. In recent years, stabilization has occurred, preventing further building deterioration. Do not enter this building as ruins can be unstable.
audioDescription: The Number Five Boiler House is located just south of the 1894 Hoist House. The building orients northeast to southwest and had an uneven roof; the western side being lower than the eastern. The boiler house is constructed from yellow brick and only a smaller single-story addition on the southern face of the building still has the corrugated metal roof. The metal trusses that supported the main buildings roof are clearly visible. Windows on the western and southern faces of the building have been removed leaving only their wooden trim. A railroad grade and part remnants of tracks can be seen entering the northern face of the building.

quickFacts.value: Contributing Structure to the Quincy Mining Company National Historic Landmark District
quickFacts.name: Significance

title: Quincy #7 Boiler House

images.altText: winter scene of dark-grey and red/white striped Jacobsville sandstone building ruins.
images.title: Quincy #7 Boiler House
images.caption: The Quincy Mine #7 Boiler House.

bodyText: The #7 Boiler House supplied steam to power for equipment like steam hoisting engines. This building housed two groups of four boilers which were separated by brick partitions. Coal fired boilers boiled water, producing the necessary steam. The steam flowed through pipes to provide power to machines sometimes located far away from the boiler house. Decorative features on the #7 boiler building include red brick archways over the doors and windows along with Jacobsville Sandstone quoins or building corners. An air pump was housed in an attached addition on the western face of the building and a stone chimney also stood next to the building on this side.
audioDescription: The Number Seven Boiler House is located southwest of the Number Four Hoist House. The building runs northeast to southwest and had two stories; the roof is now missing. The lower story had tall red brick arch-topped windows and doors. The second story has numerous rectangular red brick topped windows. A large square entrance can be seen on the north side of the second story. The corners of the buildings are accentuated by large red and white stripped Jacobsville sandstone blocks. A square single-story addition can be seen on the southwestern corner of the building. Just to the north of this addition is a square chimney base made in the same style as the Boiler House.

quickFacts.value: Contributing Structure to the Quincy Mining Company National Historic Landmark District
quickFacts.name: Significance

title: Quincy & Torch Lake RR Water Tower

images.altText: Winter scene of white building with large wood beams underneath and wooden stairs leading to a door.
images.title: Quincy RR Water Tower
images.caption: The Quincy and Torch Lake Railroad water tower.

bodyText: Locomotives on the Quincy & Torch Lake railroad ran on steam, which required a water source. This stop, located next to the locomotive house and car repairing shop, was used to replenish the train’s water supplies. Due to the steep slope of the ground in this location the water tower sits on large wooden scaffolding. Recent conservation work on the building finished in 2019 which updated its exterior and preserved it for future generations.
audioDescription: The water tower is located on the north side of Round House Road, east of its intersection with Kowsit Lats Road. This small building is rectangular in shape with a steep pitched roof clad in asphalt shingles. The water tower sits on a steep hill so prominent wooden beam scaffolding can be seen supporting the structure. The western face of the building has a set of wooden stairs leading to the entrance and a single pained window. The south face of the building has a pipe leading from its base. A sign just to the south of the building reads “water tower.”

quickFacts.value: Contributing Structure to the Quincy Mining Company National Historic Landmark District
quickFacts.name: Significance

title: Quincy 1882 Hoist House
listingDescription: As technology progressed, so did hoist houses for the #2 shaft at Quincy. The 1882 was the second of four.

images.altText: Stone building with 5 boarded windows and a metal pitched roof
images.title: Quincy 1882 Hoist House
images.caption: The 1882 #2 Hoist House.

bodyText: Built in 1882, this structure housed the second hoist for the #2 shaft. The building is a tall single-story structure made from poor-rock with arched brick details over the windows and door. Recent preservation includes the addition of a new roof, tuckpointing, and window coverings. Original dormers have been removed. In 1894 the company built a new hoist for the #2 just down the hill.
audioDescription: Located to the east of Shaft-rockhouse #2, the single story hoist house sits in the shadow of the tall rockhouse. Made of mine poor rock, the building has five windows on either side, a pitched roof, and is directly under tall metal supports that once held cables that traveled from the Hoist House to the shaft-rockhouse and then underground. On the north side of the engine house, a gravel road runs east to west and on the south side of the building is the open landscape of the former Quincy Mine with abandoned wooden rail cars, and foundational ruins to former surface operation buildings.

quickFacts.value: Contributing Structure to the Quincy Mining Company National Historic Landmark District
quickFacts.name: Significance

title: Quincy 1894 Hoist House

images.altText: Winter scene of red and white Jacobsville sandstone two story building.
images.title: Quincy 1894 Hoist
images.caption: The Quincy Mine 1894 Hoist House.

bodyText: This hoist house was the 3rd in succession to serve the #2 shaft. The building is a 22-foot tall single story made from rough red and white Jacobsville sandstone with clean cut blocks to highlight the buildings corners and sides of windows and doors. Decorative red-brick arches can be seen above the windows and doors. Long since removed, the hoist inside raised copper rock and moved men to and from their worksites underground. The building and museum inside are now part of the Quincy Mine paid tour.
audioDescription: The 1894 Hoist House is located just south of the 1918 Number 2 Hoist House. The 1894 building is constructed of red and white Jacobsville sandstone with lighter blocks detailing the corners of the building and the sides of windows and doors. Redbrick arches were used to highlight the top of the windows. The western and eastern faces of the second story, along with the roof, are now made from silver-colored corrugated metal. The roofline slopes up steeply from the northern and southern faces of the building to a single ridgeline at the top, which runs east/west. The entrance to the building is located on the western face of the building. A concrete stair leads to a single-person door on the left face and a second entrance is also on the right side. A pair of double pained windows sit in the center of this face on the first story between the entrances. Four rectangular windows are spaced evenly across the second story face. The southern face of the building has eight rectangular double pained windows spaced evenly apart.

quickFacts.value: Contributing Structure to the Quincy Mining Company National Historic Landmark District
quickFacts.name: Significance

title: Quincy Mine

images.altText: Winter scene of red and white sandstone building with snow covered parking lot.
images.title: Quincy Mine in Winter
images.caption: Quincy Mine in Hancock, MI

bodyText:
The Quincy mine was owned and operated by the Quincy Mining Company from 1864 to 1945 and was known as “Old Reliable.” The moniker came from the company regularly paying dividends to investors from 1868 until 1920. Portions of over a dozen buildings stand for visitors to see and experience. On a two-hour tour, visitors take a guided walk through the hoist house, ride a cog-rail tram, and enter the mine to learn about mining life. Shorter, surface-only tours are also available.

The Keweenaw Heritage Sites are official partners of Keweenaw National Historical Park, but are privately owned. Each site interprets and preserves an important aspect of the area's copper mining history and provides a unique visitor experience. Please contact individual sites for more information.
audioDescription: Quincy Mine is located just off US 41 north of Hancock. The welcome building and gift shop is a one-and-a-half story structure made from red and white Jacobsville sandstone that was the Supply Headquarters during the mine’s operation. The building now has a silver-colored corrugated metal roof. A wooden raised porch wraps around the western and southern sides of the building which sit adjacent to the parking lot. The entrances for the building have arched tops with brick accents. Visitors to the Quincy Mine which operated for 99 years as “old reliable” can explore numerous ruins, learn about the history of the mine, and take tours underground to see the shafts and some of the mining equipment used by the men who worked there.

title: Quincy Mine 1918 Hoist House
listingDescription: The Quincy Mine 1918 Hoist House was not only an engineering marvel, but also a company showpiece.

images.altText: tall three-story brick building with six tall rectangular windows
images.title: Quincy Mine 1918 Hoist House
images.caption: The Quincy Mine 1918 Hoist House.

bodyText: Years into the mining decline, Quincy Mine flouted its optimism for the future by investing over $300,000 to house the world's largest steam hoist. The building to house the hoist is an extravagant structure is made of reinforced concrete with a brick veneer. Finishing touches include a green glazed tile roof, which has been removed, white tile interior, and brass railings. Recent rehabilitation includes exterior concrete repair and structural stabilization.
audioDescription: The Quincy Mining Company built the Quincy Hoist building as a visual showpiece on the landscape and in its interior. Located approximately 500 feet east of the #2 Shaft-rockhouse, the large three story brick building dwarfs all other nearby structures, including the former hoist house directly next to it on the south side. This impressive building is made from reinforced concrete with a brick veneer. Multiple windows allow natural light in. A series of tall metal pulley stands once stood between the hoist house and the shaft-rockhouse but today only two remain near the shaft-rockhouse. Just east of the hoist house is a long concrete trough, now overgrown with vegetation, used to cool and condense exhausted steam.

quickFacts.value: Contributing Structure to the Quincy Mining Company National Historic Landmark District
quickFacts.name: Significance

title: Quincy Mine Dryhouse Ruins
listingDescription: The remains of a Quincy locker room, otherwise known as the "Dry."

images.altText: interpretive wayside is next to a gravel path with a long ruin foundation in the background
images.title: Quincy Dryhouse Ruins
images.caption: The Quincy Dryhouse

bodyText: The Quincy Mine provided dryhouses where miners could change into work clothes at the beginning of a shift and back into home clothes at the end of the day. At the end of shift, miners could wash up, while work clothing was hung to dry. You may notice different colors of mortar, which may indicate previous preservation efforts. This dryhouse was a two-story structure made from poor-rock.
audioDescription: The hard packed gravel pathway ends with a large rectangular rock ruin to the south and a 3 foot high rectangular wayside to the east. The ruin is of a foundation of the former Quincy Mine Dryhouse and is made of black and dark gray poor rock that came from the Quincy Mine. The pathway goes to the top edge of the foundation which extends down about 5 feet. The foundation is approximately 30 feet wide by 60 feet long and stands 12 feet tall.

quickFacts.value: Contributing Structure to the Quincy Mining Company National Historic Landmark District
quickFacts.name: Significance

title: Quincy Mine Dryhouse Ruins Parking
listingDescription: The parking area for the Quincy Mine Dryhouse ruins.

images.altText: small parking area in wooded area with accessible picnic table and rock outcroppings
images.title: Quincy Mine Dryhouse Ruins Parking
images.caption: The parking area at the Quincy Mine Dryhouse Ruins

bodyText: The parking area for the Quincy Dryhouse Ruins has two trailheads. One leads to the dryhouse and one to an overview of the historic Quincy landscape. A picnic table is available for use. Nearby rock outcroppings show evidence of glaciation.
audioDescription: A single lane gravel road leads to a small parking area that has room enough for three vehicles. The parking area has a mixed hardwood forest to the west and an ADA accessible (I think) picnic table to the side of the parking lot. To the east, a small three foot wide hard packed gravel trail leads through tall grasses and former house foundation ruins to an overlook. Beyond the overlook, expansive views of the former Quincy Mining Company property, Portage Canal, and the Huron Mountains in the far distance can be seen.

quickFacts.value: Contributing Structure to the Quincy Mining Company National Historic Landmark District
quickFacts.name: Significance

title: Quincy Mine Engine House
listingDescription: A company that owned its own railroad also need a building for maintenance and repairs.

images.altText: Rectangular stone building with a flat sloped roof and window openings along the side and four doors
images.title: Quincy Mine Engine House
images.caption: The Quincy Mine Engine House

bodyText: Built in 1889, the Quincy Engine House served as a maintenance garage for the Quincy & Torch Lake Railroad. What began with 2 bays, soon became 3, and ultimately 4, signifying Quincy's growth at the time. The engine house is a tall single-story structure made from poor-rock and has a shallow-sloped flat roof. Brick arch details can be seen above the windows. Recent preservation includes tuckpointing, a new roof, windows, and doors.
audioDescription: The Quincy Engine House is located at the southern end of the former Quincy Mining Company property. The stone masonry building has a small cluster of tall trees on the south side and an open area to the west. A set of train tracks lead to the center of the building where four tall wooden doors provided train locomotive access to the building. Constructed of mine poor rock, the long rectangular building has a flat roof that slopes from north to south with a series of tall boarded up window openings along the length of the building.

quickFacts.value: Contributing Structure to the Quincy Mining Company National Historic Landmark District
quickFacts.name: Significance

title: Quincy Mine Gift Shop (Supply Office)
listingDescription: Mining supplies of all kinds passed through these doors.

images.altText: brown and white stone building with a metal grey pitched roof next to a large parking lot
images.title: Quincy Mine Gift Shop (Supply Office)
images.caption: The Quincy Mine Gift Shop (1893 Supply Office)

bodyText: The Quincy Mine supply office was built in 1893 at an expense of just over $9,000. The supply office housed an array of mining supplies, from mine lamps to drill steels. The building is a two-story structure with gabled roof and raised foundation. The foundation is made from poor rock while the building is made from red and white Jacobsville sandstone with polished pieces to highlight the corners of the structure and the edges of windows. Arched red brick detail can be seen above the windows and doors. In the early 1990s the building was refurbished into its current use: the Quincy Mine Gift Shop.
audioDescription: The open landscape of the former Quincy Mine property has a small cluster of buildings to the east of Highway 41, at the top of Quincy Hill. The driveway entrance from Hwy. 41 to the Quincy Mine Hoist Association property leads to the former Quincy Mine Supply Office which is 50 feet from the Highway. The driveway turns to the right and becomes a large parking lot that extends around the supply office foundation and to the south. An accessible ramp leads visitors to a deck on the supply office building that offers views of the tall shaft-rockhouse to the south and the large hoist house to the east. The supply office building is constructed of brown and white sandstone that adds a decorative look to the building. Tall windows with wooden window panes bring light into the building and provide expansive views of the property.

quickFacts.value: Contributing Structure to the Quincy Mining Company National Historic Landmark District
quickFacts.name: Significance

title: Quincy Mine Man Engine Shaft
listingDescription: Man engines revolutionized how miners navigated to and from their work site.

images.altText: Rusted rail, pipes and fencing cover an old mining shaft that is surrounded by a grassy area.
images.title: Quincy Man Engine Shaft
images.caption: The Quincy Man Engine Shaft

bodyText: In early years, miners climbed ladders to and from their work sites underground. Being both grueling and dangerous, Quincy installed a man engine. This mechanical ladder system proved useful and efficient but was abandoned in the early 1890s due to the depth of Quincy. The shaft is now capped with a "bat-friendly" enclosure, one of two on the Quincy site.
audioDescription: A seemingly open landscape on the former Quincy Mining Company property reveals more than initially meets the eye. A former mine entrance is labeled Man Engine Shaft on A metal sign labeled Man Engine Shaft identifies the location of the former shaft entrance which is about 20 feet west of the sign. Today, grasses and flowers grow over mine rock rubble mounds on either side of the original entrance and a gravel path leads from the sign to the former entrance. The entrance is completely covered by a makeshift cage consisting of weathered brown steel bars and fencing attached to the bars. The flat cage top extends across the former entrance and then angles into the ground on the east side at an angle. The cage was constructed for viewing access into the former entrance while also allowing bats to leave the entrance as the former shaft serves as an important bat habitat. A small wood platform and fence allows for viewing into the cage and entrance. The man engine shaft entrance is within 20 feet of U.S. Highway 41 on the east side. Some poor rock is piled on the west side of the cage.

quickFacts.value: Contributing Structure to the Quincy Mining Company National Historic Landmark District
quickFacts.name: Significance

title: Quincy Mine Pay Office
listingDescription: The Quincy Mine Office is a prominent reminder of management's watchful eye over Quincy property.

images.altText: two-story stone building made of rust colored Jacobsville sandstone
images.title: Quincy Mine Pay Office
images.caption: The Quincy Pay Office in winter.

bodyText: Situated on the south end of Quincy Mine property, The Quincy Mine Pay Office is a prominent reminder of past corporate paternalism. Built of local Jacobsville sandstone with slate roof, this two-story structure replaced the previous office in 1897. Recent preservation efforts include new roofing, windows, and surrounding fence.
audioDescription: Located on the west side of Highway 41, the two-story former Quincy Mine Office is made of rust colored Jacobsville Sandstone. Set approximately 50 feet from the highway in an open lawn and behind a wooden picket fence that goes along a gravel driveway that is wide enough for cars to park on either side. The large building looks more like a house than an office building and has a columned entryway with six wide stairs leading to a a covered porch.

quickFacts.value: Contributing Structure to the Quincy Mining Company National Historic Landmark District
quickFacts.name: Significance

title: Quincy Oil House

images.altText: Winter scene of red and white Jacobsville sandstone building with steep corrugated metal roof.
images.title: Quincy Oil House
images.caption: The Quincy Mine Oil House.

bodyText: Now known as the oil house, this building was used to dispense carbide for miner's lamps. Carbide, when mixed with water, would emit a burnable gas. This would be the most advanced personal lighting ever in use at Quincy. This building is a single story made from red and white Jacobsville sandstone. Brick arch detail can be seen over the entrance door. Recent stabilization includes a new roof and tuckpointing, ensuring building stability.
audioDescription: The Oil house is located northeast of the Number Two Shaft Rock House. The Oil house is constructed from red and white Jacobsville sandstone blocks. It has a steep roof with silver-colored corrugated metal siding. A set of red-painted wooden doors mark the only entrance to this building located on its south side. The east and west faces have two small square ventilation holes now covered in red painted wood at the base of the structure. A earthen ramp can be seen leading to the main entrance of the building.

quickFacts.value: Contributing Structure to the Quincy Mining Company National Historic Landmark District
quickFacts.name: Significance

title: Quincy Smelter
listingDescription: Operating until 1971, the Quincy Smelter is the only remaining industrial site of its type left in the world.

images.altText: Boarded up industrial buildings made of stone and brick are within a chain link fenced in complex.
images.title: Quincy Mine Smelter
images.caption: The entrance to the Quincy smelter

bodyText:
The Quincy Mining Company built the Quincy Smelting Works on the banks of the Portage Canal in 1898. Quincy constructed the smelter to refine and ship its own copper, as well as to accept custom work from neighboring mining operations. In 1978, the Historic American Engineering Record documented the smelter complex in its study of the Quincy Mining Company. Due to the integrity of the historic resources at the site, the National Park Service then included the complex in the Quincy Mining Company National Historic Landmark District, and ultimately within the boundaries of Keweenaw National Historical Park.

The Keweenaw Heritage Sites are official partners of Keweenaw National Historical Park, but are privately owned. Each site interprets and preserves an important aspect of the area's copper mining history and provides a unique visitor experience. Please contact individual sites for more information.
audioDescription: A chain link fence surrounds the former Quincy Smelter operation, set along the Portage Canal. The smelter is a complex of brick and stone buildings, old rail trellises, and hard packed gravel surfaces between and around each building. The complex is large with a recreational snowmobile/walking trail bordering the fence to the north and the Portage Canal to the south. Hardened, melted slag from the smelting process sits in a pile a few acres in size between Highway 26 and the recreational trail. Part of a trellis remains and extends from the smelter to the slag pile. Another trellis leads from the eastern end of the site into the top part of a two-story building. Below the trellis is a long mound of gray stamp sand particles and a cluster of birch trees that have taken hold and are growing among rusted smelter carts.

quickFacts.value: Contributing Structure to the Quincy Mining Company National Historic Landmark District
quickFacts.name: Significance

title: Russell Snowplow
listingDescription: Long, harsh winters were no match for the mighty C&H Mining Company.

images.altText: black and orange snow plow train on old rail tracks
images.title: Russell Snowplow
images.caption: The Russell Snowplow

bodyText: With over 200 inches of annual snowfall, keeping the rail lines open was an endless but necessary task. Without its own power, a steam locomotive "pushed" the snowplow to clear rail lines. Nearby, you may see evidence of historic railways once used to carry people, supplies, or equipment.
audioDescription: Sitting on old rail train tracks, the black and orange C&H Russell Snowplow was used to clear tracks of snow for the Calumet and Hecla Mining Company. The snowplow is constructed primarily of wood and is composed of a 28 foot front truck attached to a 16 foot back truck. The back truck resembles a conventional boxcar with small window openings and built in storage compartments. The front truck is comprised of a pilot's house behind a large double curved wood plow resembling the prow of a ship. This large v-plow has a metal blade just above the tracks. Two large retractable steel plow extensions are located to either side of the pilot's house which extend out to cut snow banks back along the track. The snowplow was designed to be positioned in front of a steam locomotive and pushed from behind to clear drifted snow.

quickFacts.value: Contributing Structure to the Calumet National Historic Landmark District
quickFacts.name: Significance

title: Sand Storage
listingDescription: Sand was essential in the casting process.

images.altText: Winter scene of concrete building with boarded windows and doors.
images.title: C&H Sand Storage
images.caption: The Calumet & Hecla Sand Storage Warehouse.

bodyText: Calumet and Hecla’s sand storage building is located next to its pattern and foundry facilities. Sand was used in the foundry for casting tools and parts. A large supply was kept at this location. This building is a single-story structure of poured concrete and has a flat roof.
audioDescription: The sand storage building is located between the captain’s office and pattern storage warehouse. This long building is made from concrete and has a flat roof. The front face of the building has eight raised windows which have been boarded over with brown wood. Eight single person doors are set between the windows and are covered with red and brown painted wood. To the left of center of the building is a larger two-door access which is covered in red painted wood. There is a metal scaffolding set into the concrete surrounding this door and extending above the roof of the building.

quickFacts.value: Contributing Structure to the Calumet National Historic Landmark District
quickFacts.name: Significance

title: Superior Boiler House
listingDescription: Boilers provided heat and powered steam engines.

images.altText: Winter scene of poor-rock and red sandstone building with a red brick smokestack in the foreground.
images.title: C & H Superior Boiler House
images.caption: The Calumet & Hecla Superior Boiler House.

bodyText: Beneath tall, billowing stacks, coal-fired boilers boiled water. Here, the mine produced steam to power a wide array of steam powered surface equipment. These included steam hoists, which raised copper from deep underground. The boiler house is a three-part structure. One is the red brick chimney. Next to it is a tall poor-rock building with a steep hipped-roof with a small brick chimney rising out of it. The third portion is a red and white Jacobsville sandstone building with a gabled roof.
audioDescription: The Superior Boiler House is located between Mine Street and Calumet Ave, south of Church Street. The boiler house consists of two distinct connected buildings. The main entrance, and tallest building is located at the south and is in the shape of a square. It is made from grey poor-rock. The main entrance to this building is on the south face with a large garage door on the left-hand side. The rest of that face has three arched and brick-topped windows. The roof of this end of the building slopes steeply to a central point. A brick chimney can also be seen rising out of the south face of the roof. On the east face of this building a tall brick smokestack rises from an attached brick extension. This stack is fluted for support and is a rare construction style in the Keweenaw. The other portion of the building which is in the shape of a rectangle running parallel with Mine Street extends to the north of the first portion of the building. The northern portion is made from red sandstone and has numerous small arched windows along its faces. The tops of the windows are made from brick. The roof of both buildings is made from rusting corrugated metal.

quickFacts.name: Significance

title: Temple Square Calumet

images.altText: Winter scene of three churches with road in the foreground
images.title: God's Little Acre
images.caption: God's Little Acre in Calumet, MI.

bodyText: C&H donated, leased, or sold land in this area, also labeled Temple Square on early maps, for the building of numerous churches or community buildings. Managers often supported churches because they asssumed attendees would be moral, loyal and more productive. Religious beliefs and traditions provided many residents with a sence of community.
audioDescription: God’s Little Acre is located just west of the intersection of Fifth street and Red Jacket Road in downtown Calumet. A former YMCA and three former churches: the 1st Presbyterian Church, Christ Episcopal church, and Carmel Evangelical Lutheran Church, stand in this location. All these buildings were constructed prior to 1900. The former 1st Presbyterian Church is a single-story wood-frame building which is 24 feet to the eaves and has a 65-foot tower on the eastern face near the front entrance. The roof is a cross gabled style with green asphalt shingles. Large arched windows can be found around the building. A brick chimney can also be seen coming out of the roof near the eastern face. The former Christ Episcopal Church is a wooden single-story structure which is 16 feet to its eves and has a steeply sloped gabled roof. Tall rectangular windows with curved arch tops can be seen encircling the building. A large cross is present on the crest of the roof near the eastern face of the building. The former Carmel Evangelical Lutheran Church was built in 1894. It is a single story red Jacobsville sandstone building which was 20 feet to the eves and a 100-foot tower in the center of the western face. Tall rectangular windows with round arch tops circle the building with rectangular windows set below them looking into the basement level. The former YMCA building is a single-story building with an elevated foundation and hipped roof. Tall rectangular windows encircle the main floor with round arch tops on the western face. Smaller square windows can be seen near the ground on the basement level. Two single-story wooden additions were originally constructed the northern face of the building. They are now connected into one addition which serves as the main entrance. A brick chimney is found on the western end of the north face of the roof.

title: The Calumet Colosseum
listingDescription: The Calumet Colosseum is the oldest still-in-use indoor ice arena in the world.

images.altText: Winter scene of silver colored corrugated metal building with arched roof.
images.title: Colosseum
images.caption: The Colosseum ice skating rink.

bodyText: Originally constructed to house a hockey rink in 1913, the Colosseum also had removeable wooden floors for roller-skating and housed dances and conventions. After serving a dual purpose for decades as the armory for Calumet’s National Guard, today the Colosseum is home to the Calumet Hockey Association and the Calumet Copper Kings. It is considered the oldest purpose-built hockey rink in the United States.
audioDescription: The Colosseum is located on the north side of Red Jacket Road, with the long axis of the building running northeast/southwest. The building is made from silver colored corrugated metal. It has a gently curved arch roof like a balloon frame construction. The main entrance juts out slightly from the center of the face on Red Jacket Road and has a similar construction shape as the rest of the building. Three paneled windows line the front of the building in two rows with red coloring on the top of each panel set. Two smaller closed off arches flanks the main entrance with red single person doors on the front. There is a large display sign at the entrance from the road to the parking lot at the front of the building that says “Calumet Colosseum.”
